title: Friday, 17th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hi!

TT11:03am

Morning Bryce

BE11:03am

It works! Good. Delighted to say that Tony Tassell joins me today.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

What's your official title these days, Tony?

TT11:03am

glad to be back..always an honour to do....gives me a break from the main news desk too

TT11:03am

official title is deputy news editor..which means i spend a lot of time stating at the website and listening to Peter Spiegel

11:04 am
TT11:04am

you also probably hear him from your end of the newsroom...

BE11:04am

Indeed. We all have to listen to Peter a bit. His voice is one that carries.

TT11:04am

anyway doin't you normally kick off with a photo

11:04 am
BE11:04am

We do, though I've not got one.

TT11:05am

like this one

TT11:05am

11:05 am
TT11:05am

but maybe this is better

TT11:05am

TT11:05am

that is of course a reference to your epic blog of data journalism this morning

11:05 am
TT11:06am

"Here’s what we learned from ordering 213 curries at Wetherspoons"

TT11:06am

a great piece of investigatory work...and graphology

TT11:06am

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Yeah, well. I'm trying to carve out a niche for time consuming and quite pointless stuff about things people don't really care about.

TT11:07am

oh people care about wetherspoons - do you want to give us the abbrreviated summary?

BE11:08am

People get very excited indeed about 'Spoons. Rather than summarise I'll let anyone interested head over there and shout at me in the comment box.

11:08 am
TT11:08am

here is the link

TT11:08am

https://ftalphavil...s-at-wetherspoons/

BE11:08am

.... Though it's nice to see that 1800 words about the price of pub hamburgers ia currently the third-most read story on FT.com, just above "Britain prepares case to cut Brexit divorce bill"

11:08 am
TT11:08am

anyway how are the markets - what would you like to talk about Bryce

undefined
BE11:09am

Well, it's quite Friday out there. FTSE flattish again.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Sky of all things leading us up.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 931.00, up 28 (+3.10%), High: 941.00, Low: 822.50, Volume: 7.04m
TT11:09am

a very bullish take on the M&A news overnight

11:09 am
TT11:10am

Comcast and Verizon have separately approached Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox to explore potential combinations with the media company, a week after it emerged that Fox had held similar talks with Walt Disney.

Comcast and Verizon are interested in acquiring some of Fox’s entertainment assets, including its movie studio, cable channels and stake in Sky, the European pay-television group, according to people familiar with the approaches.

TT11:10am

still can't believe Rupert is going to sell

BE11:10am

That's the most interesting side of this, yes.

11:10 am
TT11:11am

he has never been sentimental about assets - he once sold my old paper The Adelaide News (his first paper) - so he could buy the profitable paper in town

BE11:12am

There's not being sentimental, and there's selling the family home and moving into a motel.

TT11:12am

Liberium takes the view that this is a sign that not only is there interest for the showbiz bits but also Sky

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Go on ..... Ian Whittaker's always worth reading.

TT11:12am

The Comcast reports seem credible given it has a large international operation via its NBCU asset and the UK is a key market for many of the US media groups. We think that, if Comcast does bid, it is likely to want 100% control of the asset so a transfer of ownership still means a full bid occurs. What it also demonstrates is that Fox’s 39% stake in Sky is still seen as a valuable asset by a number of outside parties.

TT11:13am

more on Sky itself

11:12 am
TT11:13am

Comcast’s (NR) interest in the 39% stake in Sky seems plausible. Its NBC Universal has publicly stated its interest in expanding its non-US assets for a number of years and the UK is a key market for many of the major US media giants. Comcast also has direct experience of pay-tv in the United States so it is well aware of the market dynamics and also has direct experience of the UK TV market. Comcast’s market capitalisation is $173bn (c.£130bn) so there would be no likely problem in Comcast being able to digest the asset(s).
Verizon’s interest in Sky, if it has any, would be less clear. It is more US focused and, while it operates pay-tv assets, it does not have the same experience of the UK market at Comcast does. If it does bid for the Sky stake, it would suggest quite a noticeable move into expanding its non-US assets

TT11:14am

Though i like the idea of Verizon moving into Vodafone home territory

BE11:14am

Indeed. This is a story we've chewed over for about a decade.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

The point we usually make is that Vodafone probably doesn't even want to be in the UK.

TT11:15am

(A.M -in the US? well the Trump admin seems pretty liberal on thise things)

BE11:16am

If -- by this exceptionally convoluted if-then route -- we get another dose of quad-play M&A integration stuff, I'd imagine Vodafone would be pushed into the Liberty spinoff thing sooner rather than later.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Here's UBS.

BE11:16am

We think the situation around Fox has led to uncertainty over whether the Fox/Sky deal will go ahead, leading to a pullback in the Sky share price. However, we would note that our understanding is that the bid by Fox is binding unless it fails to gain regulatory clearance. Separately, with the deal seemingly at a relatively advanced stage and all suitors for Fox reported to be interested in Sky, we do not think it makes sense for Fox to walk away. The regulator CMA is set to publish provisional findings of its phase 2 review from 18 December 2017

BE11:17am

We re-iterate our view that the Fox/Sky deal could overcome regulatory hurdles implying potential upside to the current share price with the Fox offer for Sky at 1075p per share plus dividends. However, there now appears to be several parties interested in Fox's 39% stake in Sky should the Fox/Sky deal be blocked. CMA concerns in the Fox/Sky deal seemingly relate to cross media ownership of Sky/newspapers in the UK by the Murdoch family and, to some degree, procedural and governance concerns at Fox News. However, reports suggest a deal for Fox by either Disney, Comcast or Verizon would be unlikely to involve Fox News or News Corp/UK newspapers. Therefore a deal block for Fox/Sky in our view would likely not preclude a deal involving Sky at a later stage. As a result, we think this provides support on the downside and improves the risk/reward for Sky.

11:17 am
undefined
BE11:17am

So, Carillion.

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 25.50, down 16 (-38.55%), High: 30.25, Low: 16.50, Volume: 36.51m
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Yet another warning.

TT11:18am

How is it still alive?

BE11:18am

Might not be soon. Coventant breach expected by year end.

11:18 am
TT11:18am

here is the news lead from Naomi Rovnick

TT11:18am

Carillion, a government contractor and one of the companies building Britain’s new high-speed railway, has warned it expects to breach its loan covenants and that its full-year profits will be “materially” below market expectations.

Shares in the group — which employs about 50,000 people worldwide — plunged by more than 60 per cent at the start of trade on Friday morning to 15p, having traded at around 200p as recently as July. The shares later rallied to 25p, still down 32 per cent.

The group, which has been trying to sell off chunks of its overseas business to foreign buyers as it grapples with falling earnings and rising debt, said that the start date for a “significant” project in the Middle East had slipped while plans to sell out of some public-private partnerships had also been delayed.

BE11:19am

So, the issue here is everything.

11:19 am
TT11:19am

yes...and these are not good metrics:

BE11:19am

Delays in PPP disposals, slippage in new contracts and lower than expected margin recovery.

TT11:19am

A concurrent increase in net debt to between £875m and £925m by the end of the year, Carillion said, meant that it probably would fail to meet borrowing-to-profitability targets specified by its lenders. At the lower end of the forecast range, the value of Carillion’s end-of-year debt pile represents around seven times its current stock market capitalisation of about £125m.

11:20 am
TT11:20am

and new CEO who is not going to turn up until April next year

BE11:20am

So, it's pretty clear we're on the road towards a debt for equity swap and shares are worthless.

BE11:20am

Or rather, it's hard to identify any current value in the stock.

11:21 am
TT11:21am

yes - so why did the shares rally from the lows...

BE11:21am

There are always knife catchers at these moments, who don't seem to realise the trade is very much the institutions to the retailers.

BE11:22am

Seen it a thousand times. Lonmin, Punch, etc. All the punters on their bulletin boards talking about how Balfour Beatty recovered or whatever.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Let me see if anyone's tried to put new numbers together.

TT11:23am

given the pension liabilities etc, i doubt it but is there any prospect of a buyer?

TT11:24am

if there is a debt-for-equity swap, does that trigger changes to contacts - ie they have to be put for tender?

11:24 am
BE11:24am

On the first point, we usually argue here that in these circumstances, why would you buy a company that's deep in operational hell and has nearly £1bn of net debt when you can just pick off the bits you want in a fire sale?

BE11:25am

On the second, not sure. It's a very good point. The long-run PPP stuff Carillion does has lots of break clauses fixed around financial stress.

BE11:26am

All the broker comment I've seen so far is just to note the news and say, "well, you should probably be selling".

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Peel Hunt, for instance.

BE11:26am

Carillion has announced that delays in PPP disposals, slippage in
new contracts and lower than expected margin recovery will lead
to profits being materially lower than expectations. Full-year
average net borrowings expected to be between £875m and
£925m (vs £825m to £850m). This is likely to result in covenant
breach and now a deferral process in place to 30 April. At this
point a recapitalisation plan should be being implemented. We
suspend estimates and see little value currently for equity
holders. However, it is important to note that the Carillion issues
are company specific. A flight to quality could benefit a number
of other sector players – time to think about the beneficiaries of a
‘flight to quality’. We highlight the positive updates recently
from Morgan Sindall and Kier, as well as our confidence in
Balfour Beatty’s current trading dynamics.

TT11:27am

there was a bit by Stephen Rawlinson of Applied Value

11:27 am
TT11:27am

on the project point

TT11:27am

Some of the factors to which Carillion points are timing issues, such as PPP disposals, though having said that its negotiating position is not enhanced by a potential covenant breach but other are slightly more concerning, such as the lower margins in services. But the short term concern is the potential covenant breach which the banks will now need to consider. The implications go beyond Carillion as it is involved in several projects where the conditions might typically include joint and several liability on bonds and loans. The Aberdeen Roads project might be one such situation. We suspect that the banks will be as supportive as they possibly can in this situation, especially as an equity fund raising is expected, but the price at which funds might be raised has dropped substantially today diluting existing shareholders even more. And of course, the investment case will need to be re-inforced to stand any chance of getting equity. Much of that depends on the reaction today from customers. There is, no doubt, an extensive programme of calls being made as we write. To date customers have been supportive and, in truth, not much has altered other than the timing of some expected payments but it is enough to tip the business into a different financial situation. We expect the banks will be supportive and that stakeholders will concede that a deeply discounted rights issue will happen as the alternative is far worse. In the meantime the company is exposed to vulture and other funds who might see things differently and have the backing to take action.

TT11:28am

i note Stifel has thrown in the towel in covering the company

11:28 am
TT11:28am

Stifel halted its coverage of Carillion since "We are unable to produce forecasts beyond the current year with any confidence and consequently are unable to determine a reasonable basis for a rating or target price."

BE11:29am

Hm. As we say, punter stock now. And good luck to them.

BE11:29am

Meanwhile, the deep stress of one player is usually seen as a positive for its competitors, but I'm not sure any outsourcing investor has the stomach for that kind of thinking.

11:29 am
Kier Group PLC (KIE:LSE): Last: 1,023, up 4 (+0.39%), High: 1,054, Low: 1,004, Volume: 298.52k
Morgan Sindall Group PLC (MGNS:LSE): Last: 1,425, up 25 (+1.79%), High: 1,429, Low: 1,412, Volume: 4.46k
undefined
11:30 am
BE11:30am

So, Petrofac mentioned a few times on the right.

Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 418.30, up 11.4 (+2.80%), High: 432.20, Low: 412.00, Volume: 3.63m
BE11:31am

The bid gossip that's been doing the rounds for most of the month turned up in the Telegraph this morning.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

"Schlumberger and Halliburton, as well as an undisclosed Middle Eastern bidder" circling.

BE11:31am

http://www.telegra...circle-vulnerable/

TT11:32am

a 2.8% rise in the share price does not signal huge confidence in that report

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Well, it follows on from this also Telegraph story about Petrofac rejigging its advisor roster: http://www.telegra...d-threat-takeover/

BE11:34am

It's fair to say that there's a lot of noise around Petrofac at the minute. However, when the story is "there's a rumour that there are three possible bidders including one we can't name but none has put in a bid", it's a good indication that it's market chatter rather than a leak from anyone directly involved.

BE11:02am

Hello, welcome, good morning, hey there. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the stuff and the junk.

11:36 am
TT11:36am

the price really has not being doing anything

TT11:36am

BE11:36am

There are a lot of uncertainties around Petrofac right now. A significant one is that it hasn't given any kind of detail on the likely impact of IFRS 15.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

It's also just dropped in John Pearson, formally of AMEC, and it has been doing decent contract wins .....

BE11:38am

The "takeover defence" story is a useful one to have around because it's a stealth way for management to say "we're undervalued" without having to wear the risk of saying that explicitly ......

BE11:39am

...... and maybe it's genuinely vulnerable. But we've heard nothing from anyone in the top tier of gossips to suggest we should be getting carried away.

11:39 am
undefined
TT11:39am

It it just me - this is the first time i have done ML for awhile...much less broker research around...

TT11:40am

assume it get worse under Mifid

11:40 am
BE11:40am

True. I think a lot of the good stuff is from the tiny little independents rather than the multi-service banks now.

TT11:41am

and the distribution lists for those are much smaller

BE11:41am

Also, we're a bit more cautious about sharing stuff from tiny little independents than the big banks. It's deeply unfair to chuck stuff out for firms that have customer lists in the dozens.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Can't say that about Deutsche Bank though. Quite a big bank, is Deutsche.

BE11:42am

And they're doing damage to our old friend Just Sell this morning.

TT11:42am

less big than it used to be

11:42 am
BE11:43am

True true. Still has the big art in the lobby though, which is always a comfort. Here's the just of its JE downgrade.

BE11:43am

In 2018 we expect the incoming Just Eat CEO to update the market on strategy and growth opportunities for the group. We think extension into take-away delivery, more alliances with branded restaurants and geographic expansion are all possibilities. Although these moves would be positive growth drivers in the medium to long term, they could come at the expense of near term margins. We have been consistently ahead of consensus for the last 18 months: now having incorporated added investment into our forecasts, we are 6-7% below consensus EBITDA in 2018 & 2019. With the shares now trading within 2% of our target price, the PE at multi-year highs and the valuation fair relative to growth prospects, we move to HOLD from Buy. TP unchanged at 830p.

BE11:44am

.... on strategy:

11:44 am
BE11:44am

In July 2017 Just Eat announced the intention to reinvest its revenue beat into additional growth opportunities, including increased collaboration with branded restaurants. In November, it became clearer that loss-making SkipTheDishes (STD), which also delivers orders, was driving the revenue upgrades but also weighting on the EBITDA margin. Management sounds upbeat about STD and we think a wider delivery roll out could be announced in certain markets. In the UK? We think geographic expansion and increasing focus on branded restaurants are all possibilities. While these moves would drive growth and defend Just Eat against increasing competition from integrated players like Deliveroo and Uber Eats, they could come at the expense of near term investment.

BE11:44am

.... and on valuation:

BE11:44am

Our 2017 estimates are mostly unchanged, while we trim our EPS by 3 - 6% in 2018 - 2019E. Just Eat's one year forward PE is at its all-time highs at 52x 2017 EPS. Our forecast 34% 2017-19E earnings CAGR is not enough to justify further re-rating, hence we move to HOLD. Our 830p TP is unchanged; calculation is based on the average of DCF and trading multiples vs. online peers. Risks include: investments; marketing spend; competition; M&A and cash return.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Just Eat seems reasonably likely to join the FTSE 100 at the next review, incidentally.

BE11:45am

Which I think is either end of this month or start of next.

TT11:45am

(GBKKrona - Lex was pretty downbeat on the prospects of a DB/Commerzbank consolidation https://www.ft.com...ab18-7a9fb7d6163e)

11:45 am
TT11:45am

Really Just Eat in the FTSE?

BE11:45am

I know! It's the closest thing we'll have to a blue-chip internet company!

BE11:46am

Last one we had of those was ............. Freeserve maybe?

11:46 am
TT11:46am

cripes

BE11:46am

Anyway, Just Eat and DS Smith look to be going in. Convatec and Merlin falling out. Decided on 28 Nov prices.

TT11:47am

given you knowledge of this area, is there much Just Eat can gain from consolidating HungryHouse

11:47 am
TT11:47am

are the customers sticky?

BE11:48am

Well, it's mostly a continuation of the "winner takes most" theory, which both Rocket and JE believe religiously.

BE11:49am

Which means they can collude -- sorry, did I say collude? I meant cooperate -- in exiting markets where they're just a pest for the second operator and consolidating where they have the lead.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Figures I've seen suggest about a fifth of Hungryhouse customers won't switch to Just Eat, which'll be handy because the latter can simply close down the former. But that's all guesswork.

undefined
TT11:50am

(fjp73..which gin do you recommend..)

11:51 am
TT11:52am

where shall turn to Bryce?

TT11:52am

Macro? i am told the london market is about momentum trading now

BE11:52am

(PSA: Don't pay more for your gin. Buy the cheapest stuff that doesn't mess with you in the morning, then pay up for good bitters to make it taste nice. That's my top tip of the morning.)

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Who's saying London's momentum now?

TT11:53am

well a colleague....but it might be excuse to post some grey on Goldman's top trades for 2018

BE11:53am

Thumbs up

11:54 am
TT11:54am

cool...the bank says it is a late-cycle optimist - a new one on me

TT11:54am

We are late-cycle optimists. With US equity indices at record highs and 10-year US Treasury yields only modestly off their all-time lows, we expect investors will be focused on downside risks as they enter 2018. We have a lot of sympathy for such concerns, but we see little risk that the number one catalyst for a market correction – namely recession – is likely to materialize in 2018. While, chronologically, we are late in the business cycle, we see good reason to think this expansion can extend for longer

TT11:55am

It usually pays to worry about recession risk during ‘late-cycle hiking cycles’. When central banks are hiking rates to combat late-cycle inflationary pressures, recessions often happen. But this time may be different. In particular, given the weakness of inflation and anchoring of inflation expectations in most developed economies, policy makers today have less clear motives to tighten monetary policy as aggressively or pre-emptively. Indeed, we expect the tightening of monetary policy to continue at a gradual pace by historical standards. This bodes well for the length of the current expansion.

11:54 am
TT11:55am

so consensus stuff....

TT11:55am

the other pitch phrase is - Illiquidity Is the New Leverage

TT11:55am

The late-cycle search for yield often leads to financial market imbalances. In the last cycle, the search for yield drove investors to apply high leverage to structures that featured some pretty dramatic mismatches between maturity and liquidity. When runs on funding forced an unwind of those structures and trade positions, it set in motion a downward spiral in prices. The market’s collective memory of that episode is so widely known that it has become almost a cliché to recite it.
This time around, illiquidity is the new leverage. In the current expansion, the search for yield has been equally intense, but the lessons learned in the crisis have discouraged a repeat of past mistakes. Instead of seeking levered exposure to low-spread assets with high Sharpe ratios, the search for yield has driven investors to earn incremental yield by leaning harder into liquidity premium – “anything without a Cusip”. Examples include private equity, private debt, direct lending, and commercial real estate (CRE), among others.

11:56 am
TT11:56am

the actual trades are:

TT11:56am

TopTrade #1: Position for more Fed hikes and a rebuild of term premium by shorting 10-year USTreasuries.
TopTrade #2: Go long EUR/JPY for continued rotation around a flat Dollar.
TopTrade #3: Go long the EM growth cycle via the MSCI EM stock market index.
TopTrade #4: Go long inflation risk premium in the Euro area via EUR 5-year 5-year forward inflation.
TopTrade #5: Position for ‘early vs. late’ cycle in EM vs the US by going long the EMBI Global Index against short the US HighYield iBoxx Index.
TopTrade #6: Own diversifed Asian growth, and the hedge interest rate risk via FX relative value (Long INR, IDR, KRW vs. short SGD and JPY).
TopTrade #7: Go long the global growth and non-oil commodity beta through long BRL, CLP, PEN vs. short USD.

BE11:58am

... and we'll keep sharing the 2018 previews as they arrive. Ta.

11:58 am
undefined
BE11:59am

Heading into the home straight, what's left?

BE11:59am

There's UUs, which is on an HSBC downgrade.

11:59 am
United Utilities Group PLC (UU.:LSE): Last: 799.44, down 35.06 (-4.20%), High: 827.50, Low: 795.50, Volume: 1.82m
BE12:00pm

... the gist of which is, "inflation".

BE12:00pm

United Utilities reports H1 results next week. We expect earnings to be adversely affected by the current high levels of RPI as it had 53% of its total debt index-linked debt. This means that although its revenues and regulatory capital value are also indexed for the year to March 2018, the earnings erosion will be higher than companies with more fixed rate debt. We look for operating profit of GBP342m +10% YoY.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Theme here is that the risk premium's rising, due to ....

BE12:02pm

..... the political climate and fragility of the current government; tough talking by Ofwat for the next price review; and relative lack of visibility for UU with regards to the end of regulatory period revenue adjustments.

BE12:02pm

UU is relying on financial prudency and outperformance to give it headroom into what is likely to be a challenging review. In Ofwat’s latest financial resilience report, UU does not seem to have significantly more financial headroom than its listed peers, in our view. Given its small incentive rewards to be taken at the end of the regulatory period we have less visibility than we have for other companies who are taking them in period. UU is likely to face challenges on issues of focus in PR19 such as cost to serve customers and bad debt levels.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Which all looks fair enough.

undefined
TT12:03pm

we should probably keep an eye on Mediclinic

12:03 pm
TT12:04pm

the put up or shut deadline is 5pm today i think

TT12:04pm

shares currently pricing in some uncertainty over how hardball the south africans will be

BE12:04pm

Mediclinic's fallen pretty sharply post results .....

12:04 pm
Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 557.25, down 21.25 (-3.67%), High: 574.50, Low: 557.25, Volume: 1.13m
BE12:05pm

As said yesterday, absolutely no idea if this gets done. Slightly surprised that Spire's playing hard to get.

TT12:05pm

Mediclinic sending talking tough signals in its RNS statement this morning

12:05 pm
TT12:06pm

Mediclinic takes a highly disciplined approach to capital allocation and is focused on ensuring that any offer it makes for the remaining share capital of Spire is in the best interests of Mediclinic shareholders. Accordingly, Mediclinic considers it appropriate to take into account the movement in its share price since 17 October 2017 when considering its position.

BE12:06pm

Course, to state the obvious, the sliding Mediclinic price also blunts its ability to bump.

BE12:07pm

Somewhere around here I have a sensitivity analysis .... One moment.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Ah, from Investec.

BE12:08pm

BE12:08pm

And while Mediclinic doesn't have covenants disclosed, anything above 3.5x looks improbable.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

BE12:09pm

FWIW, Investec said last week that ....

BE12:09pm

We feel an offer of 330p might be accepted by the Spire
Board, representing a c.10% premium to the 3M average and the mid-point between the initial offer and the price paid for the 29.9% stake, and set our TP at this level.

12:09 pm
BE12:10pm

Does Woodford want 330p? Absolutely no idea.

BE12:10pm

We'll see, I guess.

TT12:10pm

(on gin, drinking Two Birds at the moment - pretty decent)

12:09 pm
undefined
BE12:10pm

Okay! We're over time!

TT12:10pm

thanks Bryce for having me...

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Excellent to have you here, Tony. Let's knock off and get back to our real jobs.

TT12:10pm

enjoyed being being back on here

TT12:11pm

hah...now where is that twitter stream

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Ta, ROTR, for your participation.

TT12:11pm

(fjp73.nothing special...just with fevertree)

TT12:11pm

ciao

12:11 pm
BE12:12pm

We'll be back next week. Same time, usual stuff. Thank you, and good afternoon.

TT11:35am

the price really has not been doing anything
